text: 1 We're moving through a cornfield. At speed. The sound of children's laughter. Excited shrieking. A beautiful young girl, (MARY BOLEYN, 8), our heroine, ru through the fields, being chased by her younger brother, and sister, ANNE, (10). Touchingly, MARY is barely taller than the corn, her head skimming along the sheaves. REVERSE ANGLE TO REVEAL: the children are being watched b parents, (SIR THOMAS and LADY ELIZABETH BOLEYN).
I received a formal request for marriage today for Anne. (a beat)
From the Carey family. SIR THOMAS indicates to ANNE; the eldest. Dark-haired.
Intelligent. The obvious leader among the children.
But that's wonderful.
I turned it down. LADY ELIZABETH turns...`What?'
And offered them Mary instead. SIR THOMAS indicates  MARY, the middle child. Fair-haired.
Pretty. Sweet-natured.
Fnne's too good for William Carey. She can do (better than a merchant's son.
You underestimate Mary.
Not true. I think she's..the kinder of the two. Quite possibly the fairer. The CHILDREN, meanwhile, have started a race..
But to get ahead in this world, you need more than fair looks and a kind heart. On the field, ANNE wins. She jumps up and down, holding h aloft, as MARY flops to the floor. Vanquished.
SIR THOMAS smiles, `See?' He walks towards ANNE..
(applauding his favourite)
Bravo! Anne!
2 Bells ring high up in the bell-tower of a country church.
3 MARY, ten years older, and grown into a heavenly bride is room, surrounded by MAIDS and SEAMSTRESSES making final adjustments to her dress. A knock at the door.
May we come in..? ANNE and GEORGE enter. GEORGE lets out a low whistle..
Look at you..! Younger than me. More beautiful than me. Married before me. (a beat)
I am eclipsed. I am just the `Other Boleyn Girl.'
Hardly.
No, is this it? This is the end of the unholy trinity? GEORGE extends her arms, wraps them around his two sister intimate moment.
No, George. Never. I'll be married, that's all.. (a beat)
Apart from that - it won't change a thing. The three of them hug together, tightly..
4 A packed country church. The PRIEST officiates in Latin. is thick with incense. And winter cold..
The entire BOLEYN FAMILY is assembled on one side. FATHER MOTHER, the DUKE and DUCHESS of NORFOLK, brother GEORGE, finally ANNE..

Confirma hoc, Deus, quod operatus es in nobis.. The PRIEST sprinkles the ring with holy water. WILLIAM CA (35), puts it on MARY's finger. few rows back, a young NOBLEMAN stares at ANNE. Looks at across the church. Obviously attracted. ANNE notices.
5 The party afterwards. MUSICIANS play. The bride and groom (WILLIAM and MARY), are dancing, surrounded by WELL-WISHE other GUESTS..
Are you happy?
Very.
You don't secretly wish you'd married someone grander? With a title?
No. I want a husband who loves me. And who thinks it first thing every morning. And last thing at night.
Then you've found the right man.
ANNE is dancing with her brother GEORGE. She looks up to NOBLEMAN who was staring at her across the church..
Who is that? He was staring at me in church?
That's Henry Percy. Heir to the Duke of Northumberland. Richest landowner in England. ANNE's eyes widen in interest, "Really?"
But don't get your hopes up. He is already betrothed. GEORGE indicates a tall, haughty-looking FIANCEE beside P
Betrothed is not married, brother George. A lot can happen before you reach the altar. ANNE stares over at HENRY PERCY. Who stares back.

6 he DUKE OF NORFOLK, the most powerful nobleman in the roo close personal friend of the KING's walks with his growli to where SIR THOMAS BOLEYN and LADY ELIZABETH are sitting THOMAS gets to his feet..
Thomas.. he DUKE ignores THOMAS, and goes instead to his sister, ( ELIZABETH), and kisses her..
I think I have managed to persuade the King to come and stay with you on progress. A week-end's hunting in late summer.
But that's wonderful! Thank you, thank you so much.. (he turns to ELIZABETH)
Did you hear that, Elizabeth?
(hates the idea)
Yes.
Finally we can present George, and with luck, get him a position at court. LADY ELIZABETH excuses herself, and leaves..
These are difficult times. I have it on good authority that the Queen no longer bleeds - yet the matter of a male heir is still not resolved. a beat)
It cannot be long before the King is forced to look outside the marriage.
What? And make a bastard King of England?
A legitimized bastard. What choice does he have? (a beat)

Obviously, I've given it thought, and wondered which Howard girl I could put under his nose. Imagine the influence that would give us. To be blood family of the next King of England. Equally, imagine if another family were to achieve the same? NORFOLK indicates SIR JOHN SEYMOUR in the corner, and his loathsome, ambitious sons EDWARD and THOMAS..
What about Anne? SIR THOMAS turns, and indicates ANNE across the crowds, w dancing with GEORGE...
I realise as a `Boleyn' she is not officially a `Howard', but as your sister's daughter..
But she's your eldest, Thomas. Your first born. And your favourite. Wouldn't you prefer her to have a nice, uncomplicated, respectable marriage? Like Mary?
If Anne were an uncomplicated, respectable girl like Mary, then I'd say `yes'. But she's not. SIR THOMAS looks out at ANNE..
She's anything but.
7 SIR THOMAS and LADY ELIZABETH stand in a corner, watching party continue. ELIZABETH's face darkens..
don't like it. It would cost a fortune to make our house fit for a royal visit. Money we don't have.
And what if theDY ELIZABETH(cont'd) LA king doesn't like her?
Or if she sleeps with him but gives him a girl?
And what if you were to look on the bright side? Just once? An ominous clap of thunder outside..
Risk nothing, you gain nothing. ADY ELIZABETH stares at her husband..
hen was it that people stopped thinking of ambition as a sin, and started thinking of it as a virtue?
Easy for you to say. You've had power and wealth all your life.
Until I married you, Thomas. And I was happy to give it up. LADY ELIZABETH turns, and walks back inside.
8 ANNE knocks on the door of her father's study. She waits. Presently, the door opens. We see SIR THOMAS inside..
You asked to see me father?
Yes. Come in. SIR THOMAS closes the door.
9 MARY is in a bathroom. Being prepared by ANNE for her wed night. ANNE brushes her sister's hair. Rubs oil in her sk
o - the King himself is coming to Hever. I'm so happy for George.
Yes. But Father took me aside. It seems he has ambitions for me, too. (a beat)
He thinks I'm ANNE(coage dnow...and of not of an nt' )
unpleasing appearance...
What? What are you saying..?
It's known the King has a wandering eye. Imagine...if he were to like me?
But...you could never be more than his mistress. And that's no substitute for a husband.
But as the King's mistress the least I'd get after he finished with me would be an Earl. And if I fell pregnant? And gave him what his wife has failed to? a beat)
Quite apart from the money, it'd be a Duke at least.
But what about your happiness? Your future? ANNE shrugs, smiles..
I could be a happy Duchess.
0 MARY and ANNE enter the bedroom. A sea of candles. MARY s at the bed. A child. Suddenly terrified.
Are you nervous?
A little.
You'll tell me everything in the morning?
I promise.

No details spared? The two SISTERS hug tightly. Visibly emotional. The door opens, and WILLIAM CAREY appears in the doorway. curtseys, gives MARY a last `Good luck' kiss, then goes. MARY stares at her husband. MARY
Hold me a moment? WILLIAM CAREY envelops MARY with his arms.. MARY (cont'd)
I'm so lucky to have a man who is content with what he has. MARY looks at him.. MARY (cont'd)
You are, aren't you? WILLIAM CAREY smiles, looks at his gorgeous bride.. WILLIAM
I am the luckiest man in the world. WILLIAM reaches for the wine.. WILLIAM (cont'd)
Drink? MARY shakes her head. But WILLIAM tenderly insists.. WILLIAM (cont'd)
You should. It will hurt less. MARY nervously drinks.. WILLIAM (cont'd)

Lie back. MARY lies down. Then she lifts up her nightdress. WILLIAM down his trousers. MARY extends her hands. Inviting him to join her. WILLIAM lowers himself on top of her. He enters her. MARY smiles, in anticipation of pleasure. A side to her o might not have imagined. But one or two strokes later, and WILLIAM's knuckles whit face reddens, then he cries out, and slumps on top of her MARY looks up. Surely that wasn't it? WILLIAM (cont'd)
Thank you.
WILLIAM rolls over. MARY stares. Soon WILLIAM snores contentedly. MARY is wide awake. Confused. aybe this is how it's meant to be.

11 The thunder of horses' hooves. A huge cloud of dust. The Royal Standard flutters in the wind. Beneath it, a SO in the KING's uniform, riding hard, dirt kicking up in hi The SOLDIER is flanked by a dozen other of the KING's SOL who lead a coloumn of fifty or more RIDERS.. It's like an army. A legion riding into battle. But it's This is just the KING OF ENGLAND going away for the week- Behind the advance party, is the KING himself, (30's), ha in his prime, surrounded by a dozen or so of his closest COURTIERS, (among them the DUKE of NORFOLK), a grand, tou intimidating lot. Behind them, comes the KING's CONFESSOR, a Priest with a ornate crucifix, a small library of religious books.. Then, in a riot of colour, come the MUSICIANS, the FOOL a PLAYERS, led by the MASTER of the REVELS. Behind them, come the SQUIRES and PAGES, carrying the Kin weapons, his jousting kit, his swords, his armour, his la etc. Then come the animals: FALCONS, in cages, and the HUNTING HOUNDS, beagles and pinchers, barking in excitement, and assortment of FRESH HORSES for travelling, and hunting. And finally, bringing up the rear, another unit of ARMED and a second STANDARD BEARER.. 1

2 The BOLEYN family page, (WILLIAM STAFFORD), is perched on hill. Keeping watch. Staring into the distance.. Presently, he sees clouds of dust and the sound of thunde approaching. His expression changes...
13 Pandemonium breaks out among STAFF and FAMILY MEMBERS as STAFFORD calls out, "The King!"
14 ANNE is being dressed by MAIDS. Hearing the commotion out she rushes over to the window to see the approaching RIDE ANNE looks out of the window. Scans the approaching RIDER she finds the KING..
There he is! The young HENRY TUDOR is a dazzling, magnetic, intensely glamorous and handsome figure. A total contrast from the bloated, bearded figure of his later years.
You think he will like me?
Of course, sister. How could he not? ANNE turns to face MARY. The two SISTERS embrace tightly.

15 The entire BOLEYN FAMILY is nervously assembled outside t house, (which we notice has been transformed at great cos marquees in the gardens. Fountains. Additional staff. Sma uniforms. New extensions to the stables and kitchens). MARY is discreetly hidden, among the CROWDS. ANNE is prid place. Visibly nervous. SIR THOMAS and LADY ELIZABETH are her. The proud PARENTS. Everyone bows deeply in deference as the King arrives.
Your Majesty, you are most welcome. The King dismounts athletically. His DOGS are unleashed, excitedly..
Sir Thomas. kisses hand)
Lady Elizabeth.. A SERVANT in stiff, new uniform, with trembling hands, br wine on a tray. HENRY takes a glass..
May I present my son, George. GEORGE, visibly nervous, bows deeply from the neck. But H attention has been caught by a beautiful woman behind GEO
(while staring at MARY)
Your Uncle tells me I should have you at court. Should I?
It would be a great honour, Sir. MARY dutifully, modestly averts her eyes..
And our daughter, Anne. ENRY turns to see ANNE.
No one said anything of a daughter. ANNE curtseys deeply...
Had we known, we might have come sooner.
Your Majesty..
Perhaps you'll allow Anne to show you around our modest house?
A pleasure. ANNE offers HENRY her hand. He takes it, then leads ANNE MARY shoots ANNE a look, `Good luck'.
16 ANNE leads the KING through the house. She is followed at distance by SIR THOMAS BOLEYN. And watched by MARY and GE from a gallery above..
Here is the library.
Charming.
And through here, the observatory..
Lovely.. HENRY looks up, his eye having been caught by something..
What's that? HENRY points at an emblem above a doorway..
falcon, your Grace.
I can see that. But what's it doing there? More to the point.. (turns 360)
..not just there, but in every corner in the house?
I have no idea. Ask my father. a beat)
Perhaps because falcons are vaguely associative with field sports - field sports with aristocracy - and in the absence of a genuine coat of arms.. (shrugs)
...a man with ambition will do the strangest things. HENRY is delighted by ANNE's candour..
That's a sharp tongue you have. a beat)
I wonder what it might say about me behind my back?
Oh, his Majesty has nothing to fear from me. Unless he fears an excess of compliments. HENRY smiles, visibly charmed..
Really? And what would they be..? WATCHING FROM ABOVE, MARY smiles to herself, "Well done, as HENRY and ANNE continue down a corridor..
17 The entire BOLEYN FAMILY is assembled, frantically changi from her day attire to her finest evening clothes. SIR TH watches..
Bravo, Anne! The King was quite smitten! Told me so himself. And has requested you sit beside him at dinner. SIR THOMAS adjusts her hair..

My girl. My dear, remarkable girl. I knew you would up to the task. MARY watches. A momentary stab of jealousy at FATHER's attention. But as ANNE looks over at MARY for support.. MARY smiles. Shakes herself out of it. It's her sister. W she thinking?
18 MUSIC is being played. Everyone is dressed in their fines packed banquet hall. MUSICIANS come to a climax, loud and enthusiastic applause from everyone. HENRY gets to his fe
Well played! And, may I say.. (a modest smile)
..an excellent choice of music too! nowing smiles from the COURTIERS, SIR THOMAS and LADY ELIZABETH, the DUKE of NORFOLK, etc..
Sir Thomas, Lady Elizabeth, dear Anne. Your health.
ENRY raises his glass. Cheers and applause from the COURT A beaming SIR THOMAS raises his glass.
LATER: dinner is served. Everyone is eating. HENRY and se close COURTIERS are engaged in debate..
..I had it from the lips of the Spanish ambassador himself. That our musicians are the envy of all Europe.
..then he was flattering you, your Grace.
Our Universities and philosophers, too.
H
B
BRANDON
...another lie. That honour would have to go to the Germans. HENRY
What of our painters, then? RANDON
Years behind their Italian counterparts. The truth is far from leading the world, we're a provincial outpost, lagging far behind. HENRY
What? Is no one proud to be English? (turns to ANNE) Anne? What say you? ANNE gulps. The clanking of cutlery. All eyes on her. ANNE
Me, my Lord? clears throat) I know little of such matters, but I've not heard mention of our armies. Undefeated, I believe, in a generation. ENRY
Well said. ANNE
Or our navy? The finest in the world. HENRY
It's true. ANNE
The universities in Spain and the philosophers in Germany may be strong, but are they really the equal of Oxford and Thomas More? HENRY
Never! ANNE
I doubt there is a country that is fairer in Government, or better protected by nature from her enemies, whose people are happier or more prosperous.. HENRY
She's right, by God! She's right! HENRY is delighted. SIR THOMAS stares proudly across the ANNE. Who's hand, we notice, is shaking.
Her heart pounding in her chest.
19 SIR THOMAS stops ANNE on her way upstairs.
You did well tonight. Very well. Quite enough to be invited to court, I am sure of it. SIR THOMAS kisses ANNE's forehead..
Now go to bed. Get a good night's sleep. Because there's still the hunt tomorrow. a beat)
You must excel at that. SIR THOMAS watches ANNE go. Admiring her. Then he turns t his wife, ELIZABETH. She turns away in disgust.
20 MARY and ANNE lie together. In spoons position. ANNE is f asleep. MARY strokes her sister's hair. Eyes open. wo vulnerable, young children. 21

The following morning.. Thirty or more RIDERS, STABLE-BOYS and HORSES are gathere one side, a deafening pack of DEER-HOUNDS, (wire-haired Lurchers), barking frantically. t's a scene of great activity, excitement, and anticipati The MASTER OF THE HORSE helps HENRY mount his steed - the biggest and most glamorous stallion of all, with wonderfu ornate saddlery. number of OTHER LADIES are also going hunting, and we not they ride pillion, (ie), riding on the same horse as thei sitting behind them, holding onto them..
inally, ANNE comes out. The KING turns..
Good morning, Anne. ANNE curtseys deeply..
Good morning, your Grace.
ho will you be riding with? It's clearly an invitation. He indicates there is room fo on the back of his saddle. But ANNE fails to read the sig
On my own your Grace.
Your own..? A STABLE-BOY leads out her horse.
They have invented a new saddle which allows ladies to ride on their own. ANNE skilfully mounts the horse, and sits upright..
ut with no man to hold onto? How will you stay on the horse?
Why? The same way you hold onto yours, your Grace. A flicker behind HENRY's eyes. It's the first wrong move has made.
We'll see. ENRY yanks the reins on his horse..
Let's away! ANNE shoots a look at MARY. Then follows.
22 The thunder of hooves.. WILLIAM STAFFORD leads the way out with a pack of some fo fifty hounds. It's a stirring sight. Following the hounds thirty or forty RIDERS, led by the KING himself.
(kicking his horse)
Hah!

Up ahead, the HOUNDS start to bark. Their pace increases. They've got a scent. The BUGLER blows his horn.. The DOGS begin to increase their pace. The RIDERS urge th horses to gallop. The LADIES hold tight to their MEN.. 2
3 Up ahead, a STAG, wide-eyed, innocent, lifts it's head.. The sound of the hunting bugle and the roar of approachin footsteps, like thunder. The STAG twitches in fear, then bolts off towards the for

24 The DOGS and RIDERS roar across fields. The hounds snarl, delirious with primal agitation.. Among the RIDERS, the more advanced HORSEMEN have already up a clear lead on their weaker counterparts.. n the advanced group, are HENRY, several COURTIERS, his G and, of course, ANNE.. They jump over a hedge. One of HENRY's COURTIERS catches hedge and falls. HENRY smiles, then turns to see.. ANNE comfortably jumping the hedge herself. HENRY's smile He urges his horse to greater speed..
(kicking his horse)
Hah..!
25 The terrified DEER bolts into safety of the forest. The b HOUNDS, locked into the scent, follow. he RIDERS see this, and some pull up.
We've lost him. He's in the forest. Galloping through trees and thick forest is not for the fainthearted. But HENRY charges past, kicking up dirt..
Then we must follow.

26 HENRY weaves skilfully through low-hanging branches. He l over his shoulder, ANNE follows, close behind.. Sharp branches tear at HENRY's face. Some draw blood. Beh him, several other COURTIERS suffer lashes from the branc and pull up. But not ANNE. She kicks her horse harder. Se impervious to the whipping branches..
Hah! Ahead, the DEER darts and weaves. The HOUNDS give chase.

7 alf a mile ahead.. A steep ravine, with a sheer drop of twenty-five feet dee the bottom, a brook with dangerous rocks, then another sh climb of twenty-five feet the other side. The DEER arrives, looks, then scampers down the ravine, p by the HOUNDS. he remaining RIDERS arrive. They see the DEER scramble up other side, followed by the DOGS, slipping in the mud, an struggling with the brook. everal DOGS fall. Yelping in fright and pain as they lose footing and fall on the rocks. The KING pulls up his hors HENRY raises his hat, and salutes the DEER.

he King of England defeated by a humble fawn. The COURTIERS laugh, then they turn their horses around a off. ANNE stares. It's a clear opportunity to impress. Sh down at the rocks. A long stare, then..
(suddenly kicking horse)

Hah! The COURTIERS gasp in disbelief as ANNE lurches forward, leaps into space, heading fearlessly down the sheer ravin orse and rider almost tumble down the vertiginous, lethal But, reaching the bottom, the horse leaps across the broo scrambles up the other side.
She made it! Exhilarated, ANNE turns, breathing hard. The stares at her. The COURTIERS stare at her. long silence. Nothing but the sound of wind in the trees.

Please, your Majesty. It's not safe. HENRY turns and stares daggers at the COURTIER, `Silence' stares across the ravine at ANNE. Their eyes meet. hen he kicks his horse, `Hah!', and lurches forward. He h down the sheer ravine. The COURTIERS gasp, rush to the ed the ravine to watch. ANNE goes to the edge her side. ENRY's horse slides perilously down the ravine, then stru to clear the brook, and lands heavily in the water. he KING struggles to keep control, and as the horse tries scramble up the bank the other side, it loses it's footin

the mud, it's hooves grasping horrifically at air.. he COURTIERS cry out in horror, ANNE covers her mouth as. The KING's horse falls backwards, unseating HENRY, sendin flying, and worst of all, landing on top of him as they f tumble dreadfully down into the brook, and onto the rocks Pandemonium breaks out. The sound of shouting voices, cri horror, raising the alarm. ANNE's FACE: what has she done?
8 HENRY slowly comes to, to find himself staring at a numbe faces. A PHYSICIAN, SIR THOMAS BOLEYN, the DUKE of NORFOL or two COURTIERS, and finally, ANNE..
It's a miracle, Majesty, you have no broken bones.. HENRY flinches in agony, tries to move..
My daughter Anne is here. Would like to apologise.
(recoils, his pride hurt)
No! Get her away from me! ANNE opens her mouth, wants to protest, but is hastily us out of the room.
H
LATER: HENRY's wound is being dressed by MARY. HENRY
And who are you? MARY
Mary, your Grace. Anne's younger sister. HENRY looks her up and down.. HENRY
You've been here all week-end? MARY
Yes, your Grace. HENRY
Really? How could I have overlooked you? MARY
Next to Anne, it's easy to do. HENRY
Nonsense. HENRY sits up, takes H better look. Intrigued. a ENRY (cont'd)
Tell me about yourself. You're married? MARY
Yes, your Grace. To William Carey. ENRY
From Wolsey's office? MARY
Yes, your Grace. HENRY
Then why haven't I seen you at court? MARY
Because I have persuaded him to spend a year or two here first. We have a small manor and some land. Nothing much. But enough to start a family. HENRY
A charmed life in the country? Away from it all? MARY
Yes.
Everything I would have wished for myself. But then my brother died. a beat)
And duty called. HENRY looks at MARY, then..
You don't think he'll miss court? a beat)
A young, ambitious man?
He says not, your Majesty. MARY lowers her eyes..
But, if he ever changed his mind, I would always support him. HENRY stares at MARY.
Well said.
29 Strapped and bandaged, HENRY is helped onto his horse. Be him GEORGE BOLEYN is also on a horse, riding off to court the first time.. SIR THOMAS and LADY ELIZABETH bow, curtsey farewell..
Thank you again, Lady Elizabeth. We'll take good care of your boy.. (kissing her hand)
And Thomas.. HENRY embraces him, whispers in SIR THOMAS's ear..
You'll take care of that matter?
Consider it done, your Majesty. HENRY shoots a lingering look at MARY, which ANNE notices the King and his entourage ride off. MARY waves farewell to GEORGE. ANNE stares. Suspicious.
30 MARY and ANNE are sitting together. Presently the door op and WILLIAM STAFFORD emerges..
Your Father wishes to see you. MARY and ANNE get to their feet. STAFFORD raises his hand
Just Mary. MARY shoots ANNE a quizzical look, then goes with STAFFOR ANNE's smile fades. A flicker of suspicion. She follows..
31 An intimidating atmosphere. Dogs lie at the feet of the D NORFOLK. SIR THOMAS looks up..
Mary, I don't know what you said or did - but you obviously made a deep impression on the King. exchanges a look with SIR THOMAS)
And he has requested you come to court with immediate effect. MARY's eyes widen in disbelief..'What?' 32
ANNE listens at the door. Horrified.
What?!?
33 WILLIAM STAFFORD watches from the doorway as the DUKE of NORFOLK, WILLIAM CAREY and SIR THOMAS smile delightedly, at MARY..
ou're to pack and leave first thing in the morning. MARY shoots a desperate look at her husband..
NORFOLK
The King himself has secured you a position in the Queen's household. MARY
ut I don't want to go to court. Nor does my husband. Silence. SIR THOMAS
ell her. WILLIAM CAREY clears his throat. Avoids MARY's eyes.. WILLIAM
The King has also offered me a position. As Gentleman of the Privy Council. MARY
What? SIR THOMAS
Y'hear that? Gentleman of the Privy Council! Attending to the private and personal needs of his Majesty himself! That's the inner sanctum! MARY's shell-shocked, lost for words.. MARY
But what about our future? Here in the country? NORFOLK
Put it out of your mind. From now on your home is at court. MARY
William, please! Don't you understand what this means? MARY stares imploringly.. MARY
They will separate us. Put me in different accommodation. Where the King can always...find me. WILLIAM CAREY averts his eyes.. NORFOLK
Happily your husband understands the value of such an opportunity. (a beat) For us all.
What about Anne? Couldn't she go instead? SIR THOMAS's expression darkens. A flicker of pain.
The way that girl behaved this week-end, she can count herself lucky she still has a home.
34 ANNE'S FACE, outside the door: it's as if a knife had bee plunged into her gut. She turns and runs down the corridor.. 35
WILLIAM and MARY lie in bed. MARY is equally wretched. Te
also running down her cheeks. She stares at her husband..
How could he DO this to me? My own father. a beat)
What if we just refused?
We would be cut off. He made that clear.
But would that be so bad? MARY stares at him..
Position means nothing to me. Nor wealth. We could find somewhere. A small farm. Away from everything.
You say that now - but when you're older? And our children are grown up? (comforting her)
This won't last long. A year. Maybe two. And at the end of that - we'll we have everything we want. (a beat)
It's for our FUTURE.
ut can't you see? Do this, and we might not HAVE a future.
36 MARY is getting ready to leave. She turns a corner and `b walks straight into ANNE. A tense moment. The two SISTERS at one another..
I'm so sorry..
What for? You think I want the King? Or to be used and abused by him? (puts on brave smile)

No! You're welcome to him. I have my own plans, which don't involve becoming a rag that will one day be discarded. MARY stares, saddened, `Oh, Anne', but there's no time to She has to go. ANNE is left. Her eyes blazing.

7 MARY and WILLIAM ride through London streets escorted by SERVANTS bringing their belongings. They approach Whiteha Palace. Armed GUARDS slowly open the gates. MARY's face: as the heavy gates open. She shoots a last l the `free' world outside. Then, she rides through the Pal gates. `CLANK', the heavy doors shut behind her. The outside world has been totally sealed off. Faces appe palace windows, staring down at the `new arrivals'. mong them: is HENRY himself. He stares out of the window. MARY. Then he lets the curtain fall.
38 KATHERINE of ARAGON, (late-30's), imperious, intimidating Spanish. Surrounded by other LADIES IN WAITING, (mostly h born, Spanish, and the QUEEN's age). A SERVANT announces.
Mary Carey, Ma'am. QUEEN KATHERINE looks up..`Who?'
Who?
The new Lady in Waiting.
M
S
QUEEN KATHERINE
Really? But I was not expecting anyone. ERVANT
Appointed by...his Majesty the King. QUEEN KATHERINE
By my husband? Really? The air crackles with tension. It's school bullying. QUEEN KATHERINE

Well, then she must be some kind of gift. He must have seen in her some special talent that would please me. Tell me. What special talent is it that you have? with icy contempt) Apart from your obvious youth and beauty?
errified, MARY stammers.. MARY
QUEEN KATHERINE
oetry, perhaps? MARY
N-no.. QUEEN KATHERINE
Or dressmaking? MARY
QUEEN KATHERINE
Music! That's it! You compose? Or sing? MARY
..I'm afraid not. Your Majesty. QUEEN KATHERINE
Come, you're too modest. turns to a MUSICIAN) Signor Vasquez. The Spanish GUITARIST obliges by starting to play a well- tune of the period.. MARY
